TRACK6 TRACK4 TRACK5 TRACK3 TRACK2 Express battle to 100-98 win over Lightning in series opener http://windsorstar.com/sports/basketball/windsor-express/express-battle-to-100-98-win-over-lightning-in-series-opener http://windsorstar.com/sports/basketball/windsor-express/express-battle-to-100-98-win-over-lightning-in-series-opener#respond Fri, 13 May 2016 02:04:32 +0000 http://windsorstar.com/?p=705838 ]]> Morris Dalla Costa The London Free Press

LONDON — The goal is always to take away home-court advantage in the playoffs.

Take is the operative word and the Windsor Express did just that.

There was nothing fancy about it. No gentleness. No delicacy.

London Lightning player Tyshawn Patterson flips in the air as he and Windsor Express player Brandon Robinson fight for possession of the ball during game 1 of their NBL Canada basketball playoff series at Budweiser Gardens in London, Ont. on Thursday May 12, 2016.

The Express ripped home-court advantage away from the London Lightning, defeating them 100-98 Thursday in National Basketball League of Canada play.

The win gave the Express a 1-0 lead in the best-of-seven Eastern Division final.

But if that’s what the rest of the series is going to be like, get your tickets now.

The Lightning almost clawed back a 17-point deficit, including a 10-point deficit with a minute left. They could have won it at the buzzer but a long, long, long three-pointer by Tyshawn Patterson went off the backboard and the front of the rim.

After the game, the teams headed to the dressing room without shaking hands. Yes, it was that nasty.

The Express ran the Lightning out of the building in the third quarter. They trailed by one in that quarter, then went on a 16-0 run to take control of the game.

They outscored the Lightning 30-17, taking advantage of the Lightning’s cold shooting and their aversion to defence.

Give the Express credit — they were the far better team in the second half. They wanted the ball more and shared it. That movement gave them a lot of easy shots.

The Lightning’s second half was a disaster. They didn’t show any energy and decided to play one-on-one basketball. They took too many selfish shots. They managed to wake up when they fell behind by 17 and cut it to six but the Express responded whenever the Lightning made a run.

Windsor Express player Maurice Bolden and London Lightning player Akeem Wright chase after a loose ball during game 1 of their NBL Canada basketball playoff series at Budweiser Gardens in London, Ont. on Thursday May 12, 2016.

What drove the knife a little deeper was that it was two former Lightning players who came up big. When the Lightning cut it to eight and then six, it was Tony Bennett who hit a pair of killer threes.

But it was Maurice Bolden who gave the Express big points when Brandon Robinson didn’t.

The Express were led by Robinson with 32 points while Bolden had 22

Akeem Wright had 18 for the Lightning and 16 rebounds while Garrett Williamson had 17.

It’s the second time the Lightning and Express have met in the playoffs. The first time was in the 2013-14 season when the Express eliminated the Lightning in the Central Division final in seven games.

The two met 10 times this year with the teams splitting the series.

The teams have also split four NBL championships between them in what has to be considered as the most heated rivalry in the league.

Both teams came into Game 1 playing well despite a season of inconsistency. But playoffs are a time when veterans find their comfort zone and both teams have veterans who have been through the basketball battles.

London Lightning player Garrett Williamson is fouled by Windsor Express player Chris Commons during game 1 of their NBL Canada basketball playoff series at Budweiser Gardens in London, Ont. on Thursday May 12, 2016.

It comes down to who can respond to the pressure and playoff atmosphere and Express coach Bill Jones believes the pressure is all on the Lightning.

“We’ve been always the one that’s had to defend, now it’s London that has to defend,” Jones said. “They are the top team. Now we are pursuing them.

“We don’t have any pressure at all. The last two years we’ve had the best record overall and we were expected to win. Now we are the second-place team in our division and we can go out and pursue a championship and not worry about defending.”

Both teams played some of their best basketball in the first round of the playoffs.

“Professional basketball and professional sports in general, you have to be peaking at the right time and right now that’s what we’ve done,” Jones said. “In the last series, we played well against Niagara.”

Championship teams have the ability to bring it at the right time. The Express have plenty of that championship experience. While the Lightning only have former Express player Ryan Anderson who won a championship, the first half of Game 1 showed both teams are in it for the long haul.

“I don’t know if it’s turning on a switch but we understand what it’s about,” Jones said. “We understand that this is a new season and the guys came here for a reason.”

The veterans showed up. Robinson had 21 in the half for the Express while Wright had 11 for the Lightning.

Winning a third title for these teams is not going to come cheaply if Game 1 was any indication.

The first half was a grinding and tough affair that got nastier as it progressed.

The Express wound up leading 50-49 but there were 35 fouls called including two unsportsmanlike fouls on the Lightning and a bench technical on the Express that caused Jones to turn and chew out his players.

The Lightning had 14 more foul shots than the Express in the half. They had the chance to stretch out a lead but they missed an unacceptable 16 foul shots in the game. They also missed three easy layups.

In a series as close as this one promises to be, giving away points like that will come back to bite you.

The next game in the series is Sunday at 2 p.m. in London.

Local artists, organizations recognized by Windsor Endowment for the Arts http://windsorstar.com/entertainment/local-arts/local-artists-organizations-recognized-by-windsor-endowment-for-the-arts http://windsorstar.com/entertainment/local-arts/local-artists-organizations-recognized-by-windsor-endowment-for-the-arts#respond Fri, 13 May 2016 01:27:21 +0000 http://windsorstar.com/?p=705474 ]]> A selection of local artists and arts organizations received special recognition and support on Thursday night when the Windsor Endowment for the Arts held its biennial grants and awards ceremony.

Every two years, the WEA hands out $18,000 in grants to individuals and groups who enrich the Windsor-Essex community with their artistic efforts.

Each grant is worth $2,000. There are two categories — Emerging Artists and Arts Infrastructure — with subcategories for the different aspects of the arts: the visual, literary, performance, and community-oriented.

There are also non-monetary awards for meritorious arts leadership.

WEA president Carolyne Rourke said there were 84 applications and nominations for grants and awards this time — compared to 72 in 2014 and 29 in 2012.

“It really shows the need,” Rourke said. “We want to get the word out: We have this money, and we need to give it out.”

At the ceremony, WEA announced plans to expand its support in 2018: A new grant category, named for Dr. Eric Jackman, will provide $1,000 to the artistic initiative of a high school student or student group.

As well, the WEA hopes to increase the amount given in future grants. Specific figures remain under discussion.

“We have plans to raise it in some way,” Rourke said. The year “2018 is going to be really exciting.”

Thursday night’s event was the first time the ceremony was held at Windsor’s new Chimczuk Museum. A reception followed at the Windsor International Aquatic and Training Centre.

Rourke said the WEA is delighted to be a part of the City of Windsor’s vision of a downtown cultural hub that brings arts, recreation, and sports together.

Also announced at the ceremony were the winners of the non-monetary Mayor’s Arts Awards.

Windsor Endowment for the Arts Awards recipients Asil Moussa, right, and Grant Monroe arrive at the Art Gallery of Windsor and Chimczuk Museum Thursday May 12, 2016.

2016 grant recipients in the category of Emerging Artists:

  • Visual: Asil Moussa, filmmaker.
  • Literary: Grant Munroe, writer and spokesman for Biblioasis Press.
  • Performing Arts: Spark Plug Players, a theatre group comprised of recent University of Windsor graduates.
  • Community: Chris Rabideau, playwright, theatre director, and founder of the non-profit Arts Collective Theatre.

2016 grant recipients in the category of Arts Infrastructure:

  • Visual: Windsor International Film Festival.
  • Literary: Terrance Travis, poet, performer, and executive director of the non-profit Bloomfield House.
  • Performing Arts: Gina Lori Riley, long-time local innovator in dance and physical theatre.
  • Community: Danah Beaulieu, founder of the Art InDeed centre, which combines arts and wellness strategies.

Recipient of the Elizabeth Havelock Grant: Acclarion, a husband-and-wife classical music adaptation duo.

Non-monetary leadership award winners:

  • Visual: The Gibson Art Gallery in Amherstburg.
  • Literary: Irene Moore Davis, president of the Essex County Black Historical Society.
  • Performing Arts: Richard Householder, founder of five choral groups in Windsor-Essex.
  • Community: The Leamington Arts Centre.

2016 Mayor’s Arts Awards (non-monetary) winners:

  • Individual Artist: Erin Armstrong
  • Arts Organization: BookFest Windsor
  • Volunteer: Elissa Abboud

dchen@postmedia.com

Twitter.com/winstarchen

]]> http://windsorstar.com/entertainment/local-arts/local-artists-organizations-recognized-by-windsor-endowment-for-the-arts/feed/ 0 051216-12-trioARTs.jpg-227572854-12-trioARTs-W.jpg winstarchen Windsor Endowment for the Arts Awards recipients Asil Moussa, right, and Grant Monroe arrive at the Art Gallery of Windsor and Chimczuk Museum Thursday May 12, 2016. Belle River high school community alarmed by death threat http://windsorstar.com/news/local-news/belle-river-high-school-community-alarmed-by-death-threat http://windsorstar.com/news/local-news/belle-river-high-school-community-alarmed-by-death-threat#respond Fri, 13 May 2016 01:25:30 +0000 http://windsorstar.com?p=705492&preview_id=705492 ]]> A death threat in a hand-written note left inside Belle River high school has alarmed the tight-knit school community and has Ontario Provincial Police working to find the source.

Many parents chose to keep their children home from school on Thursday, but others feel confident both students and staff are safe given the police presence at the high school, said principal Larry Ash.

Neither Ash nor school board officials would divulge the nature of the threat or what was written to avoid jeopardizing the police investigation. They would only indicate it was a threat indicating something was to occur at the school on Friday.

“The nature of this is something a lot of people are discussing, but we want to leave it to police to analyze and focus on the threat itself so they can get to the bottom of this,” Ash said.

The high school sent a voice mail message to every parent and will continue to provide updates as the police investigation unfolds, he said.

It is the second death threat received at a local high school in the past 10 days. Walkerville Collegiate on May 2 went through a similar occurrence after an online message was posted.

It was quickly traced by Windsor police to a female student at the school who claimed she was only writing a poem and meant no harm.

Administrators with the Greater Essex County District School Board said they have not even discussed whether this might be a copycat incident. They are treating the threat at Belle River as an independent and isolated incident, said Vickie Houston, superintendent of education for the public board.

“This is an active criminal investigation,” she said. “We are working closely with police and have confidence in the investigation they are doing.”

A message left with the OPP was not immediately returned.

After speaking with many parents on Thursday, Ash said several decided to send their children to school, although many others are keeping them home until the situation is resolved.

“The mood is one of concern,” he said. “We have had several parents come right in the school to gauge the feeling and many felt fine to have their kids attend.

“We do have a police presence, so some feel it’s the safest place in Belle River right now.”

Regular activities were occurring at the school, including a scheduled poverty simulation event, Ash said.

Belle River high school, with an enrolment of 800 students, has been a school community with a family atmosphere and the threat has left some students angry at what has occurred, Ash said.

“They are upset this is happening and that someone has chosen to do this to them,” he said. “People here have a real passion for their community school. We are doing our due diligence to ensure safety.”

The parent council posted a message on Facebook about a threat and said that administration was working with the OPP to ensure the safety of students.

“I know that we’re all worried and concerned for our kids,” says the Facebook post. “A threat of any sort being made against our school has to be taken seriously.”

dbattagello@postmedia.com

]]> http://windsorstar.com/news/local-news/belle-river-high-school-community-alarmed-by-death-threat/feed/ 0 The interior of Belle River High School is seen in this file photo. (Nick Brancaccio/Windsor Star) dbattagello Windsor Public Library holding huge sale this weekend http://windsorstar.com/news/local-news/windsor-public-library-holding-huge-sale-this-weekend http://windsorstar.com/news/local-news/windsor-public-library-holding-huge-sale-this-weekend#respond Fri, 13 May 2016 01:19:31 +0000 http://windsorstar.com/?p=705729 ]]> The Windsor Public Library is holding a giant book and DVD sale on Friday and Saturday.

The main branch of the library at 850 Ouellette Ave., will be open from 9 a.m. until 5 p.m.

The library says there will be thousands of titles to choose from, with all reading and viewing tastes covered.

Thousands of hardcover books and paperbacks will be priced at $2 while mass market and small paperbacks will be priced at $1.

The library will also supply plastic bags for patrons to fill with books for a total of $5.

Audio cassettes and DVDs will be priced at $3 and magazines will be two for a dollar.

The library has previously held sales at individual branches but this is the first time they have held a large centralized sale.

The books being offered are a result of a de-selection process which sees older and heavily worn books removed from circulation.

All proceeds from the sale will go towards the purchase of new library materials.

]]> http://windsorstar.com/news/local-news/windsor-public-library-holding-huge-sale-this-weekend/feed/ 0 The main branch of Windsor Public Library at 850 Ouellette Ave. (Tyler Brownbridge / The Windsor Star) winstarthompson Linamar's Windsor plant getting "high-volume" program, says CEO http://windsorstar.com/business/linamars-windsor-plant-getting-high-volume-program-says-ceo http://windsorstar.com/business/linamars-windsor-plant-getting-high-volume-program-says-ceo#respond Fri, 13 May 2016 00:52:01 +0000 http://windsorstar.com/?p=705616 ]]> Linamar Corp.’s dramatic growth, including plans for a “significant new program” at its Windsor plant, proves that Canadian auto parts manufacturers can compete on a global scale, CEO Linda Hasenfratz, said Thursday.

Hasenfratz was among a number of representatives from industry, labour, agriculture, business and public sector groups appearing before the Standing Committee on International Trade, which is holding cross-country public consultations on whether Canada should ratify the Trans-Pacific Partnership agreement. 

 She urged the federal government to ratify the 12-country agreement, which was negotiated last year by the Stephen Harper Conservatives.

“I think there’s a lot of rhetoric all of you have heard and read that Canadian manufacturing is not competitive, and I have to say I completely disagree,” she said. “When I look at our plants in Canada, they are globally competitive. We manage our labour costs very carefully and we’re constantly working to improve our productivity every single day.”

Constant enhancements in innovation and productivity are key to competing worldwide, she said, adding that Linamar — which employs 24,000 employees across the globe — is on pace to hit record sales of $6 billion this year. Last year, the auto parts giant announced plans to invest $500 million at its Ontario plants, which employ 9,000 people.

Its Windsor plant, Exkor Manufacturing, is launching a “long-running, very high volume” aluminum component program,”  for a large assembler, she said in an interview following her submission to the committee.

Linda Hazenfratz, CEO of Linamar Corporation, speaks with the media after community consultations on the Trans-Pacific Partnership.

While she refused to disclose further details, she said the new product would “absolutely” lead to additional hiring at the plant, which employs about 200 workers who produce parts such as cylinder heads and precision engine components for automakers, including Ford Motor Co., General Motors and Toyota. 

“At Linamar, we’re a big believer in the free market, and trying to reduce trade barriers because bigger markets to sell to and to buy from is just better,” said Hasenfratz. “It means we can grow our company larger, we have more opportunities when we have a global stage to work on, so we’re a big fan of TPP and all the other trade agreements Canada has been involved in.”

If passed by Parliament, TPP would  give Canada access to a market of about 800 million people in Japan, Malaysia, the United States, Mexico, Peru, Vietnam, Brunei, Chile, New Zealand and Singapore. It also would supercede terms of the North American Free Trade Agreement between Canada, Mexico and the U.S.

Hasenfratz’s support for the TPP stood in stark contrast with the doomsday scenarios advanced by opponents ranging from Unifor to the WindsorEssex Economic Development Corporation and the Windsor Essex Regional Chamber of Commerce.

The TPP “offers no benefit to Canada’s auto industry,” said Dino Chiodo, president of Unifor Local 444, which represents hourly workers at Fiat Chrysler’s Windsor Assembly Plant. “It is hard to see how the TPP will attract new auto investment to Canada. Our fear is that it’ll simply drive it away.”

Unifor has warned that Canada’s auto assembly and parts industry could lose about 20,000 jobs because of lower content thresholds for vehicles and parts. As well, Canada submitted to further concessions by agreeing to phase out its 6.1 per cent tariff on imported vehicles, while the U.S. protected its tariff for 25 years, said Chiodo.

Chamber of commerce CEO Matt Marchand told the committee that the TPP does not prevent countries from artificially lowering the value of their currencies to make their exports cheaper.

The agreement’s consequences will add to the mounting costs faced by Ontario business, Marchand warned. “Layering TPP in its current form — on top of the existing rising cost environment in Ontario — would set us on a very uncompetitive and damaging economic path, not just in Windsor-Essex but across Ontario and Canada.”

Rakesh Naidu, interim CEO at the economic development corporation, said the TPP was a threat to the auto industry, which makes up 28 per cent of the region’s gross domestic product.

The TPP in its current form is not a “fair agreement, with a level playing field for all countries and all companies,” he said.

During questioning from the committee about the corporation’s efforts to attract automakers, other than the Detroit Three, Naidu said he was in discussions with vehicle assemblers in India and China.

“Discussions are going on (and) they’re assessing the business case,” he said in an interview outside the committee room. “It’s a constant process of back and forth. We’ve been chasing not just Chinese OEMs, but Tier 1 and 2 parts suppliers.”

Chinese and Indian car makers are eager to begin selling their vehicles in North America, he said.

“They have to get their product ready, they have to have the engineering in place, so that’s a long pipeline of things they need to do, he said. “It’s case as to whether it should be in Mexico, the U.S. or Canada. So we highlight our benefits, our strengths and try to make the case for Essex County.”

gmacaluso@postmedia.com

]]> http://windsorstar.com/business/linamars-windsor-plant-getting-high-volume-program-says-ceo/feed/ 0 Linda Hazenfratz, CEO of Linamar Corporation, speaks with the media after community consultations on the Trans-Pacific Partnership. winstarmacaluso Linda Hazenfratz, CEO of Linamar Corporation, speaks with the media after community consultations on the Trans-Pacific Partnership. Riders upset with Transit Windsor fare hike http://windsorstar.com/news/local-news/riders-upset-with-transit-windsor-fare-hike http://windsorstar.com/news/local-news/riders-upset-with-transit-windsor-fare-hike#respond Fri, 13 May 2016 00:48:41 +0000 http://windsorstar.com/?p=705667 ]]> Transit Windsor is increasing fares for the first time in more than two years, but even a small hike will sting those who use the service the most — seniors and students.

As of June 15, the cost for a single journey fare will rise from $2.75 to $3. The across-the-board hikes will also increase fares for adults, seniors and students.

“In transit, it’s very common that you should be doing regular fare increases,” Pat Delmore, executive director of Transit Windsor, said Thursday. “All the costs to providing the service are going up and if you don’t do it consistently then you end up doing much larger increases all at once.”

Both the Affordable Pass Program and the senior pass will rise by $4.40. Student passes will increase by $6. The Affordable Pass Program provides discounted passes for Ontario Disability Support Program and Ontario Works recipients, as well as low-income households.

A ride on the tunnel bus will increase from $4.50 to $5. Adult passes will jump from $87 to $95.70.

Many riders waiting for buses at the downtown terminal Thursday were upset with the hikes.

Having to pay for textbooks and school fees, St. Clair student Rebecca Oncea said that the increased fare would be a strain on her finances.

“I struggle because not having a job and going through school is hard,” she said. “It may not seem like a lot to some people, but to me it’s a lot of money.

“I rely on every cent that I have in my bank account. Paying extra for a bus pass is kind of ridiculous. Students don’t have the option to just go get a job.”

Passengers board a Transit Windsor bus at the downtown terminal on Thursday, May 12, 2016. Bus fares are going up across the board.

Retiree Mario Leclerc, who consistently uses a senior bus pass, was expecting fares to go down, not up.

“Instead of drinking pop I will be drinking water now,” Leclerc said.

The prices will make life more difficult for many people who depend on public transport, said Tamara Kowalska, executive director at the Windsor Youth Centre.

The centre focuses on supporting youth between the ages of 16 and 25 through free meals, programs and by helping them find affordable housing and employment.

Bus tickets are one of the most important donations to the centre, said Kowalska. Youth depend on access to transportation in order to attend school, work, get to job interviews and find suitable apartments and living spaces.

“If people are unable to access transportation, then as a society we’re not playing our part in helping them to transition from youth into adults,” she said.

Carol D’Hondt comments on the fare increase at the bus terminal in Windsor on Thursday, May 12, 2016.

The decision to increase fares was made in the 2016 December budget. The needs for additional funding and to align transit prices with other cities in the province led to the hikes, Delmore said.

A single journey for an adult in Toronto costs $3. Fares in Sarnia and London cost riders $2.75.

Fare increases are always all across the board, affecting students, adults, seniors and the Affordable Pass Program, said Delmore.

“When you have an increase, you have it in all categories, so that everything is consistently increased proportionately,” he said.

Kowalska said she understands why fares may be increased but believes that the Windsor community needs to find viable ways to keep transit affordable to those who depend on it.

“The increases will make life more difficult for some people and that tends to be the people who are most vulnerable,” she said. “For someone who is on a fixed income, 25 cents per ride can be a lot.”

mkatawazi@postmedia.com

]]> http://windsorstar.com/news/local-news/riders-upset-with-transit-windsor-fare-hike/feed/ 0 051216-Bus2.jpg-227570716-Bus2-W.jpg mkatawazi Passengers board a Transit Windsor bus at the downtown terminal on Thursday, May 12, 2016. Bus fares are going up across the board. Carol D'Hondt comments on the fare increase at the bus terminal in Windsor on Thursday, May 12, 2016. Retirements, stabilizing enrolment brighten job picture for teachers http://windsorstar.com/news/local-news/retirements-stabilizing-enrolment-brighten-job-picture-for-teachers http://windsorstar.com/news/local-news/retirements-stabilizing-enrolment-brighten-job-picture-for-teachers#respond Fri, 13 May 2016 00:38:36 +0000 http://windsorstar.com/?p=705622 ]]> The combination of stable enrolment and retirements have both the public and Catholic school boards feeling optimistic they’ll need to hire teachers this fall.

The Greater Essex County District School Board expects to hire 15 French-language elementary teachers while the Windsor-Essex Catholic District School Board may need more high school teachers because of better enrolment numbers at the secondary level, along with a higher than usual number of retirees.

Both boards will hire off their existing long-term occasional teachers lists.

“I’m very optimistic with the enrolment numbers coming, they’re solid,” said Terry Lyons, the Catholic board’s executive superintendent of human resources.

“That could translate into some staffing opportunities. I can’t say exactly what that is yet.”

Lyons said 40 to 50 teachers are expected to retire this June. They are evenly split between the elementary and secondary panels.

Lyons said the pleasant surprise is that enrolment is better at the secondary level. That’s an area he said the board expected to take a bit of a hit.

“The public board is getting most of the Syrian refugees, but we’re still seeing an increase in enrolment,” Lyons said.

“The only explanation is the reports of people returning home (from other parts of the country).”

It’s the continuation of a trend that surfaced last fall.

Between the public and Catholic school boards, there were nearly 1,000 more students in the two systems from outside of Essex County as of last October compared to the previous fall

 “I’m optimistic, but there are no guarantees of hiring people in the secondary schools,” Lyons said.

“We’re looking to maintain our enrolment. We’re hoping to be around 20,000 students next year.”

The public board will see 47 teachers retire this June with 36 of those being elementary teachers.

Superintendent of education John Howitt, who oversees the elementary schools, said those numbers are comparable to recent years.

Howitt confirmed the public board will require 15 new French-language teachers to meet the growing interest and the expansion of French immersion.

Whether any new hires will be required in the rest of the elementary panel won’t be known until enrolment is completed in September.

“Enrolment for kindergarten is down compared to last year, but we’re finding more parents are registering later,” Howitt said.

“We expect after late registrations, those number to be closer to last year. We’ll adjust staffing as needed in September.”

The board has already hired an additional 7.5 teaching positions in it’s English as a Second Language program to meet the needs of Syrian refugees and immigrants from other nations.

As of today, the board has taken in 301 Syrians and, as of March 21, another 73 non-Syrian immigrants.

The number of students arriving from other parts of Canada won’t be known until the fall.

“Fifty of the Syrian arrivals are in secondary school and the rest are in elementary,” said Sharon Pyke, a superintendent of education. “They’re clustered in JK, SK and Grade 1.

“They’ve mostly settled in the downtown core.”

Superintendent of education Vicki Houston, who oversees the public board’s secondary schools, said final staffing levels are still being calculated.

However, Houston said the board looks to be holding its own in terms of projected secondary enrolment numbers for the fall.

“It’s better (than originally projected),” said Houston, who added final figures will be released after they’re presented to trustees June 7. “I wouldn’t say they’re significantly better, but enrolment projections look good.”

Public board officials are expecting the fall enrolment to stay around the current level of just over 35,000 students.

dwaddell@postmedia.com

Bail or Jail aids Crime Stoppers http://windsorstar.com/news/local-news/busted-bail-or-jail-aids-crime-stoppers http://windsorstar.com/news/local-news/busted-bail-or-jail-aids-crime-stoppers#respond Fri, 13 May 2016 00:34:59 +0000 http://windsorstar.com/?p=705789 ]]> It’s that time of year where friends, family and colleagues are thrown behind bars for a good cause.

Detainees were locked in an imitation jail cell at Devonshire Mall on Thursday and relied on donations to post bail and secure their freedom.

The donations collected go to support Crime Stoppers.

The event continues on Friday.

For more information, visit bailjail.catchcrooks.com.

Yvonne Pilon, president and CEO of WEtech Alliance, works her phone to try to get out of jail at the Devonshire Mall in Windsor on Thursday, May 12, 2016. The annual Jail and Bail event left several notable faces in jail and relying on donations to secure their freedom. The event raises money for Crime Stoppers.

Yvonne Pilon, president and CEO of WEtech Alliance, pleads with Kelly Blais (left) to try to get out of jail at the Devonshire Mall in Windsor on Thursday, May 12, 2016. The annual Jail and Bail event left several notable faces in jail and relying on donations to secure their freedom. The event raises money for Crime Stoppers.

Jarvis: The straight goods http://windsorstar.com/opinion/columnists/jarvis-the-straight-goods http://windsorstar.com/opinion/columnists/jarvis-the-straight-goods#respond Thu, 12 May 2016 23:35:40 +0000 http://windsorstar.com/?p=705543 ]]> “Aggressive, relentless, unabating.”

“There is no such thing as second place.”

Is that clear enough?

It was a virtually unprecedented public forum in Windsor on Wednesday. Government, business, labour and academic leaders all gathered to discuss how to save the auto industry. And they were very frank. 

The auto industry must be part of the “fabric of our being,” said former Toyota executive Nick Marentette and Canadian Vehicle Manufacturers’ Association president Mark Nantais. 

Our commitment to this industry must be like that of former U.S. president John F. Kennedy when he vowed to put a man on the moon in 10 years, said Perrin Beatty, president and CEO of the Canadian Chamber of Commerce. (It was done in eight years.)

Because this year will determine whether Canada keeps its single most important industry, said Unifor president Jerry Dias. 

“We know what’s going to happen if GM closes its plant in Oshawa,” he said.

The Honourable Perrin Beatty, President and Chief Executive Officer, Canadian Chamber of Commerce takes part in the Windsor Essex Regional Chamber of Commerce Policy & Solutions forum held at the Caboto Club on May 11, 2016.

What about Chrysler’s paint shop in Brampton? Will Ford invest in its engine plant in Windsor?

Our share of world production is already plunging.

It “scares the hell out of me,” said Nantais. “We can lose so much so fast. And when it’s too late, it’s too late. It will never come back.”

This is just as serious as when GM and Chrysler faced bankruptcy in 2009, he said.

“Government shouldn’t treat this any different,” he said. 

Deputy Premier Deb Matthews seemed to get it. 

“We have to get our act together,” she said. “Half a million Ontarians and their families depend on this.”

Still, there seemed to be a disconnect.

We have many advantages, like our highly skilled workforce. But we also have weaknesses. And the first one — again, the panel was frank — is the maze of time-consuming bureaucracy that investors face.

Everyone talked about ProMexico, that country’s one-stop shop economic development organization. Anthony Papa, vice-president of Federal Mogul, built a 300,000-square-foot plant there in 18 months. ProMexico helped with everything, from land to labour. 

“If you’re thinking of investing in Mexico, that country makes it an easy flight path,” said Peter Frise, scientific director and CEO of Auto21 — which closed after its government funding ended.

Dr. Peter Frise, Scientific Director and CEO of Auto21 during the Windsor Essex Regional Chamber of Commerce Policy & Solutions forum held at the Caboto Club on May 11, 2016.

That’s not what happens here, acknowledged Ray Tanguay retired chairman of Toyota Canada and auto adviser to the federal and provincial governments here.

“In our case, we negotiate. In their case, they facilitate.” 

We need to change, Matthews agreed. Then she pitched the Red Tape Challenge, a website where you can suggest how to cut red tape. Are you kidding? Other countries have entire branches of government committed to the auto industry, said Papa. We have the Red Tape Challenge. 

The high cost of energy here was another concern. But both Matthews and Tanguay downplayed that.

“Energy rates are a relatively small cost of production,” Matthews said.

Ontario has already converted from coal to cleaner energy, said Tanguay. Other countries will have to do that, too, and it will cost them even more.

Amid all the calls for a national auto strategy, this was among the most revealing of the frank talk Wednesday:

“We know what to do,” said Nantais. “We haven’t done it. Twelve years ago, we knew what we had to do.”

We know what to do. And 2016 is a make-it-or-break-it year. But Tanguay’s final report won’t be ready for up to six months. 

Unifor Local 444 president Dino Chiodo, left, auto adviser Ray Tanguay and Deputy Premier Deb Matthews listen to automotive experts during the Windsor Essex Regional Chamber of Commerce Policy & Solutions forum held at the Caboto Club on May 11, 2016.

Windsor lost an opportunity for new small engine production at its Ford plant in 2014 because we didn’t have a plan, said Dias. Windsor got a retooled, state-of-the-art minivan plant, but Ontario could have gotten more. It could have gotten investment in Chrysler’s Brampton plant. We didn’t have a plan.

As Papa said, we can do this. We’ve been in this industry for 100 years. Turkey was blip in the auto industry. Now it’s a dominant force. Why? Because it figured out the impact on its economy and now “they’re hungry to build,” he said.

It’s the same with Germany. The auto industry isn’t just another industry in Germany. It’s a key strategy. By the way, a high percentage of German workers are unionized. It’s the same in Michigan and other successful U.S. states. When an automaker calls, governors jump. In Michigan, said Papa, “it’s like college football. It’s religion.”

All these jurisdictions grapple with disadvantages. But, said Frise, they acknowledge them and they adapt. 

“We sometimes don’t see that here,” he said. “We don’t have an energy cost problem? Of course we do.”

As Dias said, those countries are successful because they choose to be. But it’s an all-in effort, said Frise, starting as early as elementary and high school, where every student should be introduced to tech and where they should learn that work must be finished on time.

“There’s no happy little bubble over Windsor and Ontario,” said Frise.

It doesn’t get more frank than that — and from people who know their stuff.

ajarvis@postmedia.com

twitter.com/winstarjarvis
